An equivalent rating of record means a performance evaluation not given under 5 CFR 430, Subpart B, but meeting the following requirements:
c. Identified whether the employee performed acceptably. (

) To be used as the employee’s rating of record, an IRS performance must: a. Be completed on an officially designated performance appraisal form propriate to the employee’s position of record. b. Contain the signatures of the rating official/rater and official. c. Have been provided to the employee. d. Contain an overall rating or summary evaluation and a rating for the Retention Standard for the fair and equitable treatment of taxpayers appropriate). e. Be based on the evaluation of actual job performance for the appraisal period. f. Be retained by the rating official in the employee’s Employee File (EPF). g. Be entered into the Service’s automated personnel system. (
) Ratings of Record from other Federal agencies and Treasury bureaus may accepted for RIF purposes if they are given under the requirements of B, Part
, Office of Personnel Management (OPM) regulations or meet requirements of an equivalent rating of record specified above. (
) Each employee in a competitive area undergoing a RIF receives additional retention service credit for performance based on the average of the ee’s three most recent ratings of record received the
-year period prior to date the IRS freezes ratings before issuing specific RIF notices. (

) The IRS will provide additional retention service credit to the employees the same summary rating pattern in additional years of service on the basis the mathematical average of each employee’s ratings of record: a.

) If the average is a fraction, the Service will round up the fraction to the next higher whole number. (
) The IRS has established the use of a cutoff date of a minimum of

days prior to the planned issuance of the specific RIF notices to freeze ratings of Date in record from being used in a RIF. a. The purpose of the cutoff date is to provide sufficient time to properly determine employees’ retention standings prior to a RIF. b. The cutoff date must be stated as a specified number of days occurring prior to the issuance of the specific RIF notices. (
) After this cutoff date, no new ratings of record may be put on the record and used for RIF purposes. (

) Ratings of record received after the cutoff date may still be used for other purposes such as awards, merit promotion actions, etc. Note: To be put “on the record” means the completed valid performance is entered into the Service’s automated personnel system and is available use in a RIF. (
) The performance appraisal cutoff date may be longer than
days based the results of negotiations with the National Treasury Employees Union (NTEU). (

) No annual performance appraisal will be completed before the ending date the employee’s appraisal period to circumvent the specified cutoff date. The only exceptions to the prohibition of early appraisals are: a. A departure appraisal prepared for an employee who permanently his or her position within the last
days of the employee’s appraisal period. b. A departure appraisal prepared for an employee whose supervisor is departing his or her position within the last
days of the employee’s appraisal period. Note: These departure appraisals become the employee’s rating of record. See IRM
and
for more information on departure als used as ratings of record. (
) If an employee in a competitive area undergoing a RIF has not received actual ratings of record during the applicable

-year period prior to the date of IRS freezes ratings, the IRS provides additional retention service credit the following procedures: a. An employee who has received at least one but fewer than three ratings of record during the applicable
-year period receives retention

If an employee in a competitive area undergoing a RIF has not received three actual ratings of record during the applicable
-year period prior to the date the IRS freezes ratings, the IRS provides additional retention service credit using the following procedures:
a. An employee who has received at least one but fewer than three previous ratings of record during the applicable 4-year period receives retention
and Reduction in Force 6.430.4

service credit for performance on the basis of the value of the actual rating(s) of record divided by the number of actual ratings received. An employee who has not received any rating of record during the appli- cable

-year period receives retention service credit for performance based on the modal rating for the summary level pattern that applies to the employee’s official position of record at the time of the RIF. Examples : The modal rating would be necessary for an employee who did not receive a rating of record for a variety of reasons (e.g., active military injury compensation, an assignment under the Intergovernmental Personnel Act, work on behalf of a collective bargaining unit, or time in a pay status for a seasonal employee).
Personnel Act, work on behalf of a collective bargaining unit, or time in a pay status for a seasonal employee). (

) The modal rating is the summary rating level assigned most frequently the actual ratings of record that are: a. Assigned under the summary level pattern that applies to the official position of record on the date of the RIF. b. Given within the same competitive area. c. On the record (issued to the employee with all appropriate reviews and signatures). d. For the most recently completed appraisal period prior to the cutoff the IRS specifies prior to the issuance of notices after which no new ratings will be put on the record. (
) The IRS bases the modal rating on the competitive area undergoing a RIF. (
) At the time a RIF is contemplated for a competitive area, the Service will review the affected employees’ records to determine if the use of modal will be necessary. (
) If one or more employees in the competitive area do not have at least one rating of record during the previous
- year period, the modal rating is lated separately for each competitive area facing a RIF. (
) There is no requirement for the IRS either to determine or to use modal when every employee in the competitive area has at least one rating of during the applicable
-year time period. (
) The modal rating can only used for RIF purposes. (

) Although all IRS employees have five summary rating levels (e.g. ing,” “Exceeds Fully Successful”) based on their IRS performance, some employees in a competitive area may have performance ratings from other Federal agencies or Treasury bureaus. These performance ratings may be under more than one pattern of summary levels as specified in
CFR

) In the event that a competitive area undergoing a RIF has employees with ratings of record under other summary rating patterns, the IRS is required consider the mix of rating patterns and to specify additional retention credit for employees who have the same summary level, but are under different patterns. (
) The range of additional service credit is still limited from
to
years.
The modal rating is the summary rating level assigned most frequently among the actual ratings of record that are:

a. Assigned under the summary level pattern that applies to the employee’s official position of record on the date of the RIF. b. Given within the same competitive area. c. On the record (issued to the employee with all appropriate reviews and signatures). d. For the most recently completed appraisal period prior to the cutoff date the IRS specifies prior to the issuance of notices after which no new ratings will be put on the record.
The range of additional service credit is still limited from 12 to 20 years.
